seriesJson.title: Pacific portraits
seriesJson.description: This series explores various aspects of the Pacific region through dramatization, narration, commentary and music.

node.title: Dr. Grossman of the Solomons
node.description: Dr. Grossman, a medical missionary, is a fictitious character used to highlight postwar developments in the Western Pacific.

node.title: Matua of Fiji
node.description: This program examines problems of racial clashes and relationships in Fiji.

node.title: Dame Daisy Bates
node.description: The relationship between whites and native races in the area.

node.title: Katherine Mansfield
node.description: The recent literature of the area and the "homing" instinct of the Dominion-born.

node.title: Sir Peter Buck
node.description: New Zealand life in terms of one of its more distinguished native products. "Sir Peter Buck"

node.title: Sir Hubert Murray
node.description: Problems of administration of the native peoples in the area.

node.title: Robert Louis Stevenson
node.description: Another aspect of literary life in the Pacific.

node.title: Paul Gauguin
node.description: The attraction of the South Seas for the artist.

node.title: Father Damien
node.description: The impact of missionaries on Pacific peoples.

node.title: Herman Melville
node.description: Early literary impressions of the Pacific.

node.title: Charles Darwin
node.description: Development of scientific interest in the Pacific.

node.title: Captain Bligh
node.description: The later exploration of the area, white settlement and early conditions in Australia.

node.title: Captain Cook's early voyages
node.description: The early exploration of the Pacific and the foundation of British power there.
